title: 108_hr3948
content: The Act may be cited as the "GEAR UP & GO Act" and references amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965. It also includes a section on the continuum of services. The "GEAR UP & GO Act" amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to include provisions for awards through the first year of postsecondary education, a cohort approach to include the first year of postsecondary education, and early intervention funds for postsecondary education attendance. The "GEAR UP & GO Act" amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to include awards through the first year of postsecondary education. Section 404A of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to ensure that eligible entities do not lose their status after a grant expires. They must demonstrate the effectiveness of prior programs when applying for new grants. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for financial education and counseling. SEC. 4 amends Section 404D to include financial education and counseling for college cost requirements. SEC. 5 amends Section 404E(b)(2) by adding a scholarship cap of $5,800. SEC. 6 addresses dual/concurrent enrollment. SEC. 6 amends Chapter 2 of part A of title IV to address dual/concurrent enrollment by redesignating sections and inserting a new section 404G. The Secretary is authorized to carry out the 'GEAR UP & GO' program, allowing low-income high school students in GEAR UP partnerships or State programs to enroll in college courses while in high school without needing to apply for admission. Students must be in 10th, 11th, or 12th grade and demonstrate academic readiness for college courses. An entity receiving funding under this chapter may provide services such as offering core nonremedial college courses determined by the postsecondary institution, where students receive instruction from postsecondary faculty either at the secondary site or on-site at the postsecondary institution. Additionally, students may receive college-level instruction from high school faculty with equivalent credentials or enroll in an early college high school to earn college credit. The GEAR UP & GO program offers assistance to students in selecting core nonremedial college courses, providing tutorial services, and covering expenses for books, supplies, and transportation. The Secretary approves applications based on factors like awarding funds annually, considering dual/concurrent enrollment for college credit, and requiring assurances from applying entities.
